Die Ergebnisse zeigen ein ambivalentes Bild: Während digitale Lernformate Potenziale für Individualisierung, flexible Lernwege und selbstorganisiertes Arbeiten bieten, erschweren technische Hürden, heterogene Vorkenntnisse und begrenzte Ressourcen der Lehrkräfte die Umsetzung. Schülerinnen und Schüler bewerten das Setting überwiegend positiv, heben aber ebenfalls technische Schwierigkeiten und fachliche Überforderungen hervor. Insgesamt unterstreichen die Befunde die Bedeutung verlässlicher technischer Infrastruktur, gezielter Unterstützung sowie didaktischer und organisationaler Entwicklungsarbeit für gelingende digitale Lernprozesse.

articles_hidden.title: Shared Responsibility, Unequal Power: Mapping the limitations of multi-stakeholderism in EU’s digital governance
articles_hidden.abstract: With the adoption of the Digital Services Act, Digital Markets Act, Artificial Intelligence Act, and European Media Freedom Act, the EU has set in motion an ambitious regulatory project to shape the governance of digital platforms and AI systems. This paper maps the governance stakeholders involved in the operationalization of these four instruments and examines their distribution of powers and responsibilities. Building on existing typologies of platform governance and regulatory space theory, we introduce an analytical framework that foregrounds three structural elements–competencies, capacities, and connectedness–alongside eight regulatory functions, ranging from agenda-setting to enforcement and discourse shaping. We then operationalize this framework in the context of the standardization ecosystem, highlighting the growing prominence of standardization bodies as central actors in multi-stakeholderism. Our analysis shows that, despite the promises of multi-stakeholderism for more democratic and cooperative governance configurations, in practice this approach often disregards material power asymmetries. This reality privileges technocratic expertise and industry stakeholders over public-interest actors, hindering ultimately a more equitable and democratic governance paradigm. We conclude by arguing that pursuing strategic autonomy, as the EU boasts, requires reducing the regulatory power of private actors and strengthening capacities of actors normatively and materially grounded in the public interest.
articles_hidden.subjects_osf: Science and Technology Law, Public Affairs, Public Policy and Public Administration, Communication

articles_hidden.title: O APAGAMENTO INDÍGENA E O LEGADO DO EVOLUCIONISMO CULTURAL NA PRODUÇÃO ACADÊMICA SOBRE RACISMO NO BRASIL
articles_hidden.abstract: Este artigo tem o objetivo de verificar de que forma o evolucionismo cultural justificou e reforçou uma supremacia cultural branca no Brasil, instituindo uma narrativa em que os negros são seus principais antagonistas e os povos indígenas deixaram de existir após a colonização, descrevendo como essa crença carrega um legado até hoje na produção acadêmica brasileira sobre racismo no país. O artigo analisa a aparição das perspectivas indígenas em 44 trabalhos recomendados na primeira página de 5 buscas das principais palavras-chaves sobre racismo do Google Acadêmico brasileiro, fazendo um comparativo ao protagonismo das perspectivas negras para representar o corpo racializado que sofre racismo no Brasil. Com a análise, fica evidente a invisibilidade e a exclusão dos povos originários em todos os trabalhos, apresentando, na maioria das vezes, desde algumas mínimas citações até a inexistência de qualquer aparição indígena. Esse apagamento contribui para uma compreensão limitada e excludente sobre racismo no país, tanto no meio acadêmico, quanto na disseminação do assunto na sociedade em geral.

articles_hidden.title: Ethische Herausforderungen und Potenziale KI-gestützter Chatbots in der Hochschullehre: Eine medienpädagogische Perspektive
articles_hidden.abstract: Die fortschreitende Digitalisierung bietet der Hochschulbildung neue Potenziale, insbesondere durch den Einsatz von Künstlicher Intelligenz (KI). Chatbots können selbstgesteuertes Lernen unterstützen, Lernprozesse individualisieren und zur Qualitätssteigerung in der Lehre beitragen (Hobert/Berens 2019). In diesem Beitrag wird ein Praxisbeispiel vorgestellt, in dem ein KI-gestützter Chatbot Studierende in einem bildungswissenschaftlichen Modul der Lehramtsausbildung begleitet, indem er Fragen beantwortet und Lernmaterialien bereitstellt, um das Selbststudium zu fördern. Neben praktischen Aspekten stehen die ethischen Implikationen im Fokus, wie der Schutz von Autonomie und Datenschutz sowie die Notwendigkeit von Transparenz im Lernprozess. Ein besonderer Schwerpunkt liegt auf der Förderung ethischer Kompetenzen im Umgang mit KI-Systemen, da Studierende nicht nur technologische, sondern auch kritische und medienpädagogische Fähigkeiten entwickeln müssen, um digitale Werkzeuge reflektiert und verantwortungsvoll zu nutzen (Knaus 2018; Kuka/Hörmann/Sabitzer 2024). Der Beitrag plädiert dafür, dass die Integration von KI nicht nur technologische Anpassungen erfordert, sondern auch eine umfassende medienpädagogische Auseinandersetzung, die Studierende und Lehrende mit Future Skills ausstattet. Abschließend wird die Rolle der KI als integraler Bestandteil der Hochschulbildung diskutiert, um Lernprozesse ganzheitlich und verantwortungsbewusst zu gestalten. The ongoing digital transformation provides new opportunities for higher education, particularly through AI-powered chatbots. These systems can support self-directed learning, personalize educational processes, and enhance teaching quality. This paper presents a practical example from teacher education in which a chatbot assists students by answering questions and providing learning materials. Alongside practical considerations, the ethical implications of chatbot usage—especially autonomy, data protection, and transparency—are discussed. A particular focus is placed on fostering ethical and media-pedagogical competencies, as students must develop critical skills to engage responsibly with AI systems. The paper argues that integrating AI in higher education requires not only technological adaptation but also a pedagogical approach that equips students and teachers with future-oriented skills.
articles_hidden.subjects_osf: Digital Humanities, Philosophy, Teacher Education and Professional Development

articles_hidden.title: Libraries as a ‘Third Place’ for Remote Workers: A Survey of Australian Workplace Preferences
articles_hidden.authors: Simon Wakeling, Philip Hider, Xi Wen Chan, Matthew J. Xerri
articles_hidden.abstract: As remote and hybrid work become more common, many workers are seeking ‘third places’ -alternative environments outside the home and office - to work and connect. This study explores the role of public libraries as alternative workplaces for remote workers in Australia. Drawing on survey data from 225 remote workers recruited via Prolific, we examine who uses libraries for remote work, how often, and why. Weekly, around eight per cent of respondents use libraries for at least half a day, a rate similar to that for coworking spaces, while a further one in three would consider doing so. Libraries are valued for quietness, affordability, internet access, and a sense of community, but limited privacy and restricted hours remain barriers. The findings highlight the library’s potential to meet workforce needs and offer practical implications for library managers seeking to design spaces and policies that better support remote workers and their wellbeing.

articles_hidden.title: Onlineberatung lehren – Onlineberatung lernen: Ein reflexives Lehrkonzept für die Hochschullehre
articles_hidden.abstract: Der Beitrag stellt ein Lehrkonzept für ein Hochschulzertifikat in Onlineberatung vor, in dem reale bzw. simulierte Beratungsfälle, mentorielles Feedback, kollegiale Supervision und schriftliche Reflexion eng miteinander verzahnt werden. Theoretisch basiert das Konzept auf Mentoring, Reflexionskompetenz und forschendem Lernen. Empirische Auswertungen aus drei Durchgängen zeigen sowohl förderliche als auch herausfordernde Aspekte des Lernprozesses, insbesondere im Umgang mit Feedback, bei der Strukturierung von Beratung und der Nutzung digitaler Beratungsformen. Der Beitrag zeigt, wie Reflexion als qualitative Methode den Transfer zwischen Theorie und Praxis in der Onlineberatung unterstützt und zur Professionalisierung beiträgt. The present article introduces a teaching concept that integrates real-life online counseling cases into a university certificate program for online counselors at the X. Central elements of the concept include the reflection on one's own counseling practice, collegial supervision, and mentored feedback. The reflection on the concept highlights both supportive and challenging aspects of the learning processes, with particular emphasis on dealing with feedback, the application of counseling methods, and critical self-reflection. The article explores how reflection, as a methodological component of inquiry-based learning, contributes to transferring theoretical knowledge into the practice of online counseling and supports the development of counseling competencies.
articles_hidden.subjects_osf: Adult and Continuing Education, Higher Education, Social Work, Counseling

articles_hidden.title: Who Lives in a STEM Desert?
articles_hidden.authors: Brian Holzman, Bethany Lewis, Jinhua Zhao, Hao Ma
articles_hidden.abstract: STEM deserts, similar to education deserts, are rural, suburban, and urban areas where students have limited access to school-based STEM curriculum and coursework opportunities. Using administrative data from the Houston Independent School District following a state policy change to high-school graduation requirements, this study develops measures of STEM deserts and identifies the students most likely to live in them. Findings reveal that Black and Asian/Pacific Islander students, students from non-English-speaking households, and those from lower-socioeconomic neighborhoods are disproportionately likely to live in STEM deserts compared to White students, students from English-speaking households, and those from higher-socioeconomic neighborhoods.
articles_hidden.subjects_osf: Science and Mathematics Education, Geography, Public Affairs, Public Policy and Public Administration

articles_hidden.title: Counterpublics and haunted publics: Media imaginaries of landscape transformation in Central Kalimantan
articles_hidden.abstract: This chapter examines media imaginaries surrounding resource commodification in Central Kalimantan, Indonesia, with a focus on events in 2020. It analyses two distinct yet interconnected media events. The first pertains to how the politics of natural resource commodification are debated and how various actors are positioned within these discussions. The second concerns the circulation of accounts of supernatural phenomena. The data include personal online exchanges from 2020–2021; three annual volumes (2018–2020) of a Central Kalimantan newspaper; selected news items from internet-based media (2017–2020); Twitter conversations from 2020 under various keywords; and selected YouTube videos featuring supernatural phenomena published between 2017 and 2020. First, the analysis argues that the Central Kalimantan mediascape is fragmented: established media outlets explicitly represent various state interests while claiming to serve the public, whereas social media discussions and circulating multimedia narratives often provide a counternarrative—if not constitute a counterpublic—serving as platforms for citizens to mobilise and articulate their interests. Second, the chapter introduces a new type of circulating discourse, termed “haunted publics,” in which accounts of supernatural events circulate in ways distinct from conventional counterpublics, yet the emergent effects of this circulation can still generate political critique. Third, consistent with previous research, it shows that discourses on supernatural events and resource politics are interrelated, even when they do not directly engage one another.

articles_hidden.title: Event-level modelling of showering behaviour in German households: Triangulating smart-meter, in-situ survey and contextual public data
articles_hidden.authors: David Morizet, Pablo Pereira-Doel, Xavier Font, Caroline Bastide, Juliette Brun, Valérie Drey
articles_hidden.abstract: Residential water demand is strongly shaped by showering behaviour, yet quantifying drivers at the event level remains rare. We first explored and identified key patterns across 8,550 sensor-logged showering events from 319 German households. We then combined this high-resolution smart-meter data with time-stamped post-shower surveys to analyse shampoo-shower duration. The Gamma mixed model (14 predictors spanning demographics, context, in-shower behaviour and hair characteristics) explained 68.4% of deviance (AIC = 4281.6). Behavioural predictors showed the clearest associations: showers with two or more shampoo applications were 27% longer than those with one, while showers with three or more water pauses were 28% longer than those with one. Some contextual and demographic predictors also mattered: soft water areas were linked to 23% longer durations, and younger/mid-age adults had durations up to 31% longer than adults 50+. Other factors (gender, employment, household composition/size, home type, bills responsibility and most hair characteristics) showed small or uncertain effects after adjustment. Findings demonstrate how smart metering, event-level behavioural data and robust modelling can reveal actionable levers for demand-side management, behavioural interventions and product design.

articles_hidden.title: How Citizens Search for Information about a Climate Policy: Role of Search Suggestions, Political Beliefs, and Intuition
articles_hidden.abstract: When confronted with diverse political information, people often engage with content supporting their beliefs. While many studies investigate selective exposure based on what sources or content users consume, fewer explore whether selectivity occurs in how users navigate to political information—namely, in how they search. Using a representative survey of Swiss citizens (N = 1,070), I examine whether users select attitude-consistent search queries to look for a climate policy that was voted on in early 2025 in Switzerland. This study finds only limited signs of selective exposure: while intention to vote for or against the initiative was not related to the query stance, respondents’ climate beliefs partially influenced query selection. I further test whether selective exposure is greater when users choose queries from recommended options than when they formulate them independently, and discuss the role of expected vote outcome, political beliefs, and cognitive factors in query selection.

articles_hidden.title: Public Backlash Against Science Communicators: Conceptualization and Qualitative Analysis of Perceptions, Effects, Responses, and Context Factors
articles_hidden.authors: Niels G. Mede, Sophia Charlotte Volk
articles_hidden.abstract: Public backlash against scientists increasingly draws concern. It can originate from citizens, politicians, or journalists and range from legitimate criticism of scientific work to harassment and physical attacks. However, criticism and harassment also affect science communication professionals, which has received comparably little public and scholarly attention. Our study addresses this gap. Drawing on qualitative interviews with 15 university communicators from multiple countries, we develop a conceptual model that systematizes their perceptions of public backlash, the effects on them or their institutions, response strategies, and context factors. Our analysis introduces criteria for distinguishing legitimate criticism from illegitimate backlash and describes negative but also positive effects on science communication. The results elucidate proactive and reactive response strategies and highlight the influence of topic characteristics, routes of backlash, and sociopolitical contexts. Overall, they offer a new perspective on the normative imperative for public engagement. We discuss implications for science communication research and practice.

articles_hidden.title: Unreliable Evidence: Flawed Vaccinated vs. Unvaccinated Comparisons in Canada’s COVID-19 Vaccine Mandates
articles_hidden.abstract: Background: Canada’s 2021–2022 COVID-19 vaccine mandates and passports were implemented with the stated aim of reducing transmission and hospital burden. In the absence of randomized controlled trial evidence for these endpoints, policymakers relied on vaccinated vs. unvaccinated comparisons from surveillance data and observational studies, as well as ungrounded simulations, despite known methodological limitations that rendered such evidence unreliable for public health policies with rights implications. Methods: We systematically critiqued Canadian public health surveillance reports and advisory briefs (Public Health Agency of Canada, Public Health Ontario, Ontario COVID-19 Science Advisory Table) together with related studies, identifying seven key biases classified by severity (critical/catastrophic), correctability, and scope. Distortions were quantified using published rate corrections, classification rules, time-series data, and population trends. Results: Critical biases included >40% misclassification of early post-vaccination cases as unvaccinated and an 80-fold overestimation of senior unvaccinated hospitalization rates due to denominator errors. Additional critical biases—age-standardization obfuscating low-risk youth trends, testing fluctuations understating breakthrough cases, and misattribution rendering COVID-19 hospitalizations an invalid metric for burden—further distorted policy evidence. Catastrophic biases—selection and cumulative methodology—rendered group comparability invalid. Population trends showed case and hospitalization surges despite >80% vaccination coverage, with vaccinated individuals dominating Omicron-era infections. Simulation studies retroactively justifying mandates contradicted real-world data with ungrounded counterfactuals used to estimate unproven benefits. Conclusions: Pervasive, uncorrected biases in observational comparisons invalidated causal claims of transmission or hospital burden reduction. Progressive reliance on weaker evidence—coupled with expert bodies' lack of transparency in emphasizing unproven benefits while dismissing dissenting views—highlights a systemic failure to meet evidentiary standards for public health policies with rights implications. This analysis underscores the need for greater scientific rigor in interpreting observational data through real-time bias correction, transparent limitation reporting, and risk-stratified approaches to uphold evidentiary standards, ethical proportionality, and accountability. These lessons hold global relevance for evidence-based public health policy.
articles_hidden.subjects_osf: Public Affairs, Public Policy and Public Administration, Science and Technology Studies, Social Statistics

articles_hidden.title: Vertrauensbildung in der Onlineberatung: Chancen und Risiken Künstlicher Intelligenz aus Sicht von Fachkräften
articles_hidden.abstract: Die fortschreitende Digitalisierung eröffnet neue Möglichkeiten für die Onlineberatung, insbesondere durch den Einsatz von KI. Onlineberatung bietet zeit- und ortsunabhängige Unterstützung und zeichnet sich durch Niedrigschwelligkeit und Zugänglichkeit aus. Ein zentraler Faktor für ihr Gelingen ist das Vertrauen zwischen Beratenden und Klient:innen. KI kann hierzu durch transparente Kommunikation, personalisierte Interaktionen und kontinuierliche Verfügbarkeit beitragen, wirft jedoch zugleich Fragen nach ethischer Nutzung und Datenschutz auf. Der Beitrag untersucht, wie Vertrauen in der Onlineberatung entsteht, welche Rolle KI dabei spielt und welche Barrieren der KI-Nutzung bestehen. Im Fokus stehen Chancen und Risiken des KI-Einsatzes aus Sicht von Fachkräften, die im Rahmen einer empirischen Erhebung beim DGSF-Online-Fachtag 2024 erhoben wurden. Advancing digitalisation opens new opportunities for online counselling, especially through the use of AI. Online counselling offers low-threshold, accessible support independent of time and place. A key success factor is the trust established between counsellors and clients. AI-supported tools can foster this trust through transparent communication, personalised interactions and continuous availability, while also raising challenges regarding ethical data use and privacy. This paper examines how trust is built in online counselling, the role AI plays in this process, and what barriers professionals identify regarding AI-supported counselling services. Special attention is given to opportunities and risks based on findings from an empirical study conducted at the DGSF Online Symposium 2024.
articles_hidden.subjects_osf: Digital Humanities, Social Work, Counseling, Communication

articles_hidden.title: Lernsettings - Räume für Lernen gestalten
articles_hidden.abstract: Der uneinheitlich definierte Begriff des Lernsettings reicht von der Beschreibung dessen Komponenten bis hin zur Festlegung von didaktischen Gestaltungselementen und damit verbundenen Zielsetzungen. Es existieren einige beschreibende Modelle, die jeweils unterschiedliche Schwerpunkte setzen. Im nachfolgenden Artikel werden einige Gestaltungsparameter von Lernsettings, sowohl allgemein als auch auf digitale Arrangements bezogen, skizziert. Dabei kann festgehalten werden, dass es keine einheitliche Gestaltungslogik geben kann angesichts der Vielfältigkeit der mit einem Lernsetting verbundenen möglichen Ziele, Methoden und Zielgruppen sowie Inhalte.

articles_hidden.title: ‘I had everything I needed to deal with this. I just couldn’t see it.’ Understanding the experience of subtle abuse in heterosexual women of high educational and socio-economic status to aid recognition
articles_hidden.authors: Rosemary Parkinson, Stephanie T Jong, Sarah Hanson
articles_hidden.abstract: Intimate partner abuse (IPA) conducted solely on a subtle level has not previously been studied, inhibiting therapist recognition and leading to potential further victim harm. This qualitative study explored the experience of subtle abuse amongst women of high educational and socioeconomic status (HESES) and therapists who had worked with similar women, to aid recognition. One over-arching theme of incongruence occurred in all a victim’s relationships, including with themselves and with therapists. Victims’ abuse-responding behaviours and abuse-related shame linked with their HESES. Identification of incongruence among victims and others, such as therapists, is central to the recognition of subtle abuse.
